First, the 20 measurements from each site were averaged as one reflectance curve sample, resulting in 9∼12 samples for each plant species. Second, the reflectance curves were divided into 100 consecutive 5 nm-wide hyper-spectral bands by taking the average from its original five wavelengths without losing much information (the raw spectral resolution is 3.3 nm). Moreover, reﬂectance data were averaged to represent four broad multi-spectral wavebands according to band ranges of TM (blue – B: 450∼520 nm; green – G: 520∼600 nm; red – R: 630∼690 nm; near-infrared – NIR: 760∼900 nm).
